Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Titanium Microelectromechanical Systems: Strength and Strengthenability

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objectives of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award are: 1) to advance fundamental understanding of size-dependent plasticity in titanium-based microelectromechanical systems (Ti MEMS); and 2) to develop means for strengthening Ti MEMS in situ, after they have been fabricated. The former is motivated by the importance of such understanding in establishing guidelines for reliable design, while the latter is motivated by the limited material selection capability and poor fabrication process versatility in MEMS. To achieve the first objective, mechanical testing will be used to characterize deformation response of micromechanical structures produced using recently-developed techniques for deep reactive ion etching of Ti. To achieve the second, diffusional alloying will be used to strengthen Ti MEMS with interstitial nitrogen solute. Understanding gained in these studies will help elucidate mechanisms underlying size-dependent strength in Ti, as well as foster development of new technological capabilities with direct relevance to both conventional MEMS and emerging biomedical microdevice applications.

Research, teaching, and outreach efforts will be integrated to help inspire and prepare the next generation of scientists and engineers, as well as engage a local community that is rich in ethnic and socioeconomic diversity, but not well-represented in higher education. These efforts will also help support continued growth and diversification of the U.S. science and engineering (S&E) enterprise, and will leverage a new partnership with the California Science Project, a statewide network focused on enhancing science instruction. Specific activities to be undertaken will include those focused on: 1) supporting diversity in S&E higher education; 2) inspiring interest in advanced S&E studies; and 3) promoting K-12 S&E interest and awareness.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to further advance an emerging manufacturing technology that provides, for the first time, the opportunity for fabrication of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) from titanium (Ti), a material that offers potential for greater robustness, reliability, and performance relative to more conventional micromechanical materials, such as silicon, glass, and polymers. Key outcomes from this project included:

1)      The development of a new process that enables realization of minimum feature sizes as small as 150 nm for Ti MEMS devices, which represents a 5-fold improvement relative to the previous state-of-the-art, and opens the potential for numerous new applications, including the modulation of cellular response around implanted devices to improve safety and efficacy;

2)      The demonstration of the potential embodied in nanocrystalline Ti for MEMS applications, which will provide opportunity for increasing strength significantly, and thus, expanding the performance envelope of Ti MEMS, and the application space within which such devices can be used;

3)      The education and training of two domestic graduate students in a range of fields, including advanced manufacturing, materials science, and biomedical engineering, thus providing a solid foundation for future careers in related industries; and

4)      The creation of a new outreach event that engaged over 100 middle/high school students and their parents from the local community to increase public awareness of, and interest in STEM educational and career paths.

 


Last Modified: 04/16/2019
Modified by: Masaru Rao

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project sought to further advance an emerging manufacturing technology that provides, for the first time, the opportunity for fabrication of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) from titanium (Ti), a material that offers potential for greater robustness, reliability, and performance relative to more conventional micromechanical materials, such as silicon, glass, and polymers. Key outcomes from this project included: 1) The development of a new process that enables realization of minimum feature sizes as small as 150 nm for Ti MEMS devices, which represents a 5-fold improvement relative to the previous state-of-the-art, and opens the potential for numerous new applications, including the modulation of cellular response around implanted devices to improve safety and efficacy; 2) The demonstration of the potential embodied in nanocrystalline Ti for MEMS applications, which will provide opportunity for increasing strength significantly, and thus, expanding the performance envelope of Ti MEMS, and the application space within which such devices can be used; 3) The education and training of two domestic graduate students in a range of fields, including advanced manufacturing, materials science, and biomedical engineering, thus providing a solid foundation for future careers in related industries; and 4) The creation of a new outreach event that engaged over 100 middle/high school students and their parents from the local community to increase public awareness of, and interest in STEM educational and career paths.
